intro: Corydalis curviflora var. giraldii, commonly known as the Sierra larkspur, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its slender, upright stems and clusters of blue to purple flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in rocky or open habitats, often in mountainous regions. It has palmate leaves with five to seven lobes, and its flowers are spurred at the base, a feature common in the Fumariaceae family. Corydalis curviflora var. giraldii is valued for its ornamental beauty and is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
